detection of a large transaction would through up alerts, detection of tx or wallets which are connected suspicious tx as well.  No idea if they used an automated mechanism, or if they had to manually review and had enough time before the phisher could move the funds (i'm assuming the LPed funds had receipt tokens and they managed to pause movement of those receipt tokens and thus prevent them from redeeming them)

likely using a service like hexagate, forta, hypernative for threat detection and in some cases automated response.

I'm happy to read that! I'm way more radical than that, but if we can at least agree that that's a discussion which needs to happen, then we are moving forward.

Because crypto's current __full unconditional transparency __really is dystopian and likely more dangerous (for people's safety) than useful (for AML).

Sir, yes. I am 100% agree and supportive of compliance friendly full automous privacy protocol as long as its possible to trace illicit funds. There should be a mechanism that allow only authorized law enforcement agents to trace certain transactions without any third party involvement with limited access to only that transaction.

See, even in that scenario, only law enforcement should be able to trace funds. Not everybody. I mean, imagine a website where anybody can type an IBAN or a credit card number and get all the transactions info in detail. How many people would be killed because of that?

That's exactly what a crypto explorer proposes for the "future of finance"...
And promoting full privacy only will bring more regulative pressure on Defi, not utility.
Defi has to find a solution to money laundered on defi protocols otherwise it wonâ€™t end well.
If you are making money and in profit today, thanks to full transparency.
Crytoâ€™s full uncoditional transparency is part of Bitcoin whitepaper and original idea behind. Itâ€™s wht we promote to regulators over 10 years as legal marketing.

That's exactly what is happening. The leading reasoning we hear currently is: __"Because it's hard to catch money laundering, let's surveil everybody's money",__ __"Because it's hard to fight terrorists, let's read everybody's private messages"__, __"because it's hard to catch criminals, let's put cameras in everybody's homes",__ etc.

And even if you agree on that approach, it still means that only law enforcement need to be able to access that information. Not my neighbor, nor the cashier I just paid my coffee to.

Privacy is about controlling what we show (selective transparency). Crypto's full unconditional transparency is crazy.

If today bitcoin network or ethereum network are legally accessible its due to transparency not privacy. There are international agreements that all Sovereign states agree and there is no world a law enforcement canâ€™t trace flow of funds because of design of protocol.

If it goes like that, there will be no market at all. 

There is no explanation in law as â€œsorry the victimâ€™s fund came here but we cant trace anymore because its defi and we have yo respect privacy.
1st one is an operational one and it might not seem big but there is a market for it. Also, if one build this then I assure you every project gonna use it
No, a kind of tool needed for lf a law enforcement dig for money laundering. Obviously tool of tornado useless because a scammer or hacker never legally have to show source of transactions.
one issue does not exclude the other btw :)

Yeah. That's an option. But like Tornado Cash, being built "on top" of the transparent base (instead of happening at protocol level) means that you can still be punished or blacklisted for using it...
Is the biggest issue on defi at the moment employees sees each other salaries or Lazarus can launder 1.5billion dollars within few months?
isn't enough the tx report tool?

Privacy is about controlling what you show and share, and to whom. So, imo, compliance and AML can be very well be part of it.

For me, it's full unconditional transparency which is problematic. I mean, even if I agree on law enforcement looking into my stuff, I don't want the people I interact with to have that same access. 

Imo, we've only got accustomed to this excessive transparency because Bitcoin and Ethereum did not have the math and tech at the time to add at last some privacy in the base protocol (there is that famous post by Hal Finney saying, after 10 days of running Bitcoin, that it lacks privacy).
Privacy tools should be built with compliance friendly tools. Sadly railgun or tornado doesnâ€™t solve that problem and create a vast hole for laundering.

You guys seriously think in like 5min increments in life.

Without financial privacy, you cannot keep your family safe as you get hunted down by people looking to take your money. You cannot support the causes you care about without big brother making your life hell. You cannot pay friends and family without the filthy hand of the government being in there to take their cut of that too. You cannot opt out of a system you were opted into at birth and are forced at gunpoint to support forever with 80% of your money. You cannot leave your assets to your family after youâ€™ve left this world because the leeches will be there too. 

Think more than 5 mins ahead ffs.

Afaik, there is only one privacy-by-default blockchain with smart contracts (as per your wording, it would be __"public smart contracts with private addresses"__).

It does many things right regarding censorship-resistance: dApps frontends decentralized and running locally, chain lightweight enough for every wallet to run its own node, token txs indistinguishable from base coin txs, etc.

Unfortunately, its microscopic mcap is proof that people don't care about privacy, and don't even really care about tech itself. ğŸ˜–

I fear that Privacy DeFi (PriFi?) is far from happening anytime soon... ğŸ™„

This is why I've been looking for the perfect privacy L1 since like mid-2018. Unfortunately all I've found is garbage with, at best, ethereum level block times and questionable ux. There's no network out there that satisfies the normie desire for speed while also offering real privacy by default (private smart contract with public addresses, that doesn't count). Only failed projects, scams and dreams.

That being said, unfortunately I don't think most people care. They just can't foresee the issues pseudonymous chains cause, they have to directly experience these problems first and have their lives be severely impacted before they can even start to think about the fact maybe they've actually got something to hide.

There is no good censorship. Simp "web3" teams which think they need a legal entity (which is retarded, they don't) necessarily fall to big daddy directives, and lock themselves into a web2 workflow in a web3 market (a market significantly smaller than any thing they would be able to accomplish in web2 by being similarly gov-simp, ironically).

There can only be freedom, or censorship. And they way you get freedom is by making sure everyone MUST be free. Like, for example, dusting everyone involved, every user of these apps and protocols, every founder address, everyone who ever touched their stuff, with Tornado and Railgun dust.
